The '''Loyola Marymount Lions''' are the athletic teams that represent [[Loyola Marymount University]], a [[Association of Jesuit Colleges and Universities|Jesuit institution]] in [[Los Angeles]], [[California]]. The school competes in [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] [[Division I (NCAA)|Division I]], with its primary affiliation in the [[West Coast Conference]], an organization consisting solely of religiously-affiliated schools.
==Teams== ===Basketball=== The Lions burst onto the national basketball scene in the late 1980s under coach [[Paul Westhead]]. His teams led Division I in scoring in 1988 (110.3 points per game), 1989 (112.5) and 1990 (122.4).<ref>[[#ncaa2010|NCAA 2010, p.39]]</ref> LMU's 122.4 point per game in 1990 was still a record as of October 2010.<ref>[[#ncaa2010|NCAA 2010, p.5]]</ref> As of October 2010, Loyola Marymount held the five highest combined scoring games in Division I history. Four of the five occurred during Westhead's career, including a record 331 in the 181â150 win over [[United States International University]] on January 31, 1989.<ref>[[#ncaa2010|NCAA 2010, pp.28â29]]</ref>
LMU's current men's head coach is [[Max Good]].
====Hank Gathers and Bo Kimble==== [[Hank Gathers]] and [[Bo Kimble]] were recruited to the [[University of Southern California]] by Head Coach [[Stan Morrison]] and his top assistant, David Spencer. They were joined by high school All-American, Tom Lewis, and Rich Grande as the "Four Freshmen" star recruiting class.<ref name="UNRAVELING">Harvey, Randy - [http://articles.latimes.com/print/1986-05-13/sports/sp-6015_1_george-raveling Un-Raveling at USC: A Failure to Communicate]. ''Los Angeles Times'', May 13, 1986</ref><ref>Florence, Mal -[http://articles.latimes.com/1986-01-19/sports/sp-1402_1_free-throw-shootingFourFreshmen Make Sweet Music in USC Victory]. ''Los Angeles Times'', January 18, 1986. ''The young players--Hank Gathers, Tom Lewis, Bo Kimble and Rich Grande--all contributed Saturday afternoon as USC beat Arizona State, 81-72, at the Sports Arena.''</ref> Following an 11-17 season coaching USC, Morrison and Spencer were fired after the 1985-86 season was over, despite winning the PAC-10 the previous year. It was reported that the players would not remain unless certain conditions were met, including having a say in the next coaching staff.<ref name="UNRAVELING" /> USC hired [[George Raveling]] as the next head coach of the Trojans.<ref>Fleischman, Bill-[http://articles.philly.com/1986-03-28/sports/26082131_1_stan-morrison-george-raveling-usc Raveling Leaves Iowa To Take Reins At USC]. Philadelphia Daily News, March 28, 1986</ref> Raveling gave the players a deadline to respond whether they would remain on the team. When they did not respond, he revoked the scholarships of Gathers, Kimble, and Lewis.<ref>Florence, Mal [http://articles.latimes.com/1986-04-29/sports/sp-2355_1_usc-freshmenScholarships Taken From 3 USC Freshmen : Lewis, Gathers and Kimble Receive Word From Raveling]. ''Los Angeles Times'', April 15, 1986</ref> Raveling's controversial<ref>Sands, Vernon-[http://articles.latimes.com/1986-04-05/sports/sp-21706_1_george-raveling-usc-team-insensitivity At Least, If Raveling Gives a Hoot, Then So Does His USC Team]. ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'', April 5, 1986</ref> statement was, "You can't let the Indians run the reservation," he said. "You've got to be strong, too. Sometimes you have to tell them that they have to exit."<ref name="UNRAVELING" /> Kimble and Gathers transferred together from USC to Loyola Marymount. Lewis transferred to Pepperdine. Grande remained at USC.
In the 1988â89 season, Gathers became the second player in [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] [[Division I (NCAA)|Division I]] history to lead the nation in scoring and rebounding in the same season, averaging 32.7 points and 13.7 [[Rebound (basketball)|rebound]]s per game.<ref name=hersch>{{cite news |last=Hersch |first=Hank |title=Gathers 'round The Rim |date=February 13, 1989 |magazine=[[Sports Illustrated]] |url=http://cnnsi.printthis.clickability.com/pt/cpt?expire=&title=Hank+Gathers+helped+Loyola+Marymount+win+181-150+-+02.13.89+-+SI+Vault&urlID=412992972&action=cpt&partnerID=289881&fb=Y&url=http%3A%2F%2Fsportsillustrated.cnn.com%2Fvault%2Farticle%2Fmagazine%2FMAG1126533%2Findex.htm |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5x1Aa0Pi1 |archivedate=March 7, 2011}}</ref><ref name=maxey>{{cite news |last=Maxey |first=Wendell |title=Hank Gathers' legacy endures 20 years after tragic on-court death |date=March 4, 2010 |newspaper=[[USA Today]] |url=http://www.usatoday.com/sports/college/mensbasketball/2010-03-04-hank-gathers_N.htm |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5x177Uo2X |archivedate=March 7, 2011}}</ref> In the 1989â90 season, Kimble led the nation in scoring averaging 35.3 points per game. Both Gathers and Kimble were [[1990 NCAA Men's Basketball All-Americans|consensus second team All-American]] selections in 1990.<ref>[[#ncaa2010|NCAA 2010, p.23]]</ref><ref>{{cite web |author=NCAA |authorlink=National Collegiate Athletic Association |title=NCAA Men's Basketball Records (Award Winners) |date=October 31, 2008 |page=137 |url=http://web1.ncaa.org/web_files/stats/m_basketball_RB/2009/Award.pdf |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5x1Whs6c7 |archivedate=March 8, 2011}}</ref>
The Loyola Marymount men's basketball team will forever be remembered for the death of star player [[Hank Gathers]] (#44), who collapsed during the second round of the [[West Coast Conference|WCC]] tournament on March 4, 1990, and for the team's subsequent run to the Elite Eight in the 1990 NCAA Men's Basketball Tournament. Gathers and teammate [[Bo Kimble]] (#30) had their jerseys retired by LMU.
===Water polo=== The women's water polo team was the WWPA Champion in 2001, 2002, 2003, 2004, 2005, and 2007.
At the conclusion the 2004 season, Loyola Marymount's women's water polo team lost to the University of Southern California (USC), 10-8, in the [[NCAA Women's Water Polo Championship]] game at [[Stanford Cardinal|Stanford University]]'s Avery Aquatic Center.
